title: Molten salt solar receiver and procedure to reduce the temperature gradient in said receiver

abstract: Molten salt solar receiver and procedure to reduce the temperature gradient in said receiver. The receiver consists of at least one panel of semi cylindrical geometry, formed by a combination of vertical pipes. The receiver (10) is supplied with a heat transfer fluid made up of molten salts which originate from a recirculation system which is composed of a mixture deposit (6), a hot salt storage tank (9) and a cold salt storage tank (8); the mixture tank (6) which is supplied by a part of the hot heat transfer fluid (4) which exits the receiver (10) and the cold heat transfer fluid (5) which exits the cold salt storage tank (8); the hot salt storage tank is connected to the exit of the receiver (10) so that a part of the heat transfer fluid which does not recirculate is stored (3).
claims: 1. Tower type molten salt solar receiver, through which the heat transfer fluid circulates, characterised in that the receiver (10) is supplied with a heat transfer fluid made of molten salts which originate from a recirculation system which is composed of a mixture deposit (6), hot salt storage tank (9) and cold salt storage tank (8); the mixture tank (6) which is supplied with a part of the hot heat transfer fluid (4) which exits the receiver (10) and with cold heat transfer fluid (5) which exits the cold salt storage tank (8); the hot salt storage tank is connected to the exit of the receiver (10) so that a part of the heat transfer fluid which does not recirculate is stored (3).
2. Molten salt solar receiver according to claim 1 characterised in that said receiver is a pipe receiver.
3. Molten salt solar receiver according to claim 2 characterised in that said receiver is a vertical pipe receiver.
4. Molten salt solar receiver according to claim 2 characterised in that said receiver is a horizontal pipe receiver.
5. Molten salt solar receiver according to claim 1 characterised in that a mixture of molten nitrate salts are employed as a heat transfer fluid.
6. Molten salt solar receiver according to claim 5 characterised in that a mixture of molten nitrate salts are employed as a heat transfer fluid, this composition being 60% NaNO3 and 40% KNO3.

7. Molten salt solar receiver according to claim 1 characterised in that it is composed of an impulsion pump (7) for the exit from the mixture deposit (6) to the receiver (10) situated on the top of the tower and several regulation valves (15, 16, 17 and 18) at the entrance of each panel (11, 12, 13, 14 and 15) of the receiver.

8. Procedure to reduce the temperature gradient in a molten salt solar receiver and, as described in the previous claims, characterised in that, to reduce the gradient, part of the molten salt flow which exits the receiver at high temperature is recirculated and is mixed with a flow of cold salts, so that the heat transfer fluid of salts which enter the receiver is at an intermediate temperature, which reduces the thermal gradient between the entrance and exit of said fluid.

9. Procedure to reduce the temperature gradient in a molten salt solar receiver according to claim 8 characterised in that it comprises the following stages:
Supply of the flow of molten salts (1) provided by a mixture deposit (6) on the upper part of the panels (11, 12, 13 and 14) which the receiver is composed of (10) through several regulation valves (15, 16, 17 and 18), making it circulate inside the pipes, absorbing the concentrated solar energy,
the flow of hot molten salts (2) is collected on the lower part of the receiver, recirculating a part of the flow (4) to the mixture deposit (6) with the other part (3) being stored in the hot salt storage tank (9),
supply to the mixture deposit (6) of cold salts (5) originating from a cold salt tank (8) and by the flow of hot salts from the receiver which is recirculated (4).
